title: The Adventures of Penguin and Panda
author: Brenda Maier
description:
Penguin and Panda should not be friends. The very idea is absurd. Penguin likes to build things and Panda likes to nap. Panda munches bamboo and Penguin gobbles cheese puffs and jam-banana sandwiches. Penguin never powers down and Panda has a hard time powering up. There is no way their friendship would ever work. Except somehow, it does.

In the tradition of Narwal and Jelly, here is an extremely commercial illustrated chapter book/graphic novel series for young readers. Bright, kid-friendly illustrations are full of humor. An odd couple buddy comedy featuring two buddies who clearly love each other. The author is an elementary school teacher, so she knows the voices, the audience, and she knows what teachers look for in books like these. 

Simple dialogue belies the depth of Penguin’s and Panda’s conversations; dig deep and you’ll find hints of moral philosophy—just like in Winnie the Pooh.

At $9.99 for 4 complete stories, plus a few kid-friendly extras, the package is a bargain. Five-book commitment from the outset, with the first two titles debuting simultaneously so kids won’t have to wait for another, and so booksellers know we’re serious in our support for this series.

author_bio: Brenda Maier is an author, elementary school teacher, and mother of five. Her hobbies include tricking kids into thinking for themselves, reading way past her bedtime, and dragging her husband and kids to places they’ve never been, whether they want to go or not.
illustrator_bio: Fanni Mézes is an artist living in Budapest, Hungary. After graduating university as a product design engineer, she pivoted to art school and set out to illustrate books for young readers. The Penguin and Panda books mark her U.S. debut. Fanni and her husband are the parents of one daughter; they all enjoy reading and watching cartoons together.

about_summary: Penguin and Panda should not be friends. The very idea is absurd. Penguin likes to build things and Panda likes to nap. Panda munches bamboo and Penguin gobbles cheese puffs and jam-banana sandwiches. Penguin never powers down and Panda has a hard time powering up. There is no way their friendship would ever work. Except somehow, it does.
about_promotable_points: It’s got two best friends who are polar opposites, but they can still be friends.
The characters’ experiences mirror those of children’s. Kids struggle with emotions like frustration, guilt, and anger just like Penguin and Panda do.
They’re positive. Even if someone makes a mistake, the stories center on hope, positivity, and kindness.
about_bookstore_shelf: In the early graphic chapter book section, or wherever Narwhal & Jelly is.
about_diff_competitors: Penguin & Panda focuses on very authentic, relatable, child-mirroring situations.
There’s a bit of wisdom in each book. There’s a sort of generalized bit of knowledge or philosophy in each one.
Though the characters struggle with various things, they are kind and empathetic, always with a happy ending. You can count on them.
about_audience: Elementary school-aged kids from 5-10, depending on their ability to read. I don’t see this as a read-aloud that teachers will do, but we might be able to market them for reading groups with questions to download. And of course they’re super engaging for classroom libraries and kids shopping with their parents.
author_long_bio: Brenda Maier is a writer, mother of five, public school teacher, and board member of OAGCT, the Oklahoma affiliate of the National Association for Gifted Children. Among her books for young readers are The Little Red Fort and The Little Blue Bridge, both of which have been named to notable reading lists. She lives in Oklahoma with her family and enjoys visiting classrooms around the country to share her passion for reading, writing, and goal-setting. Her hobbies include tricking kids into thinking for themselves, reading way past her bedtime, and dragging her husband and kids to places they’ve never been, whether they want to go or not. You can visit her at brendamaier.com

title: Ellie in First Position
author: Brian Freschi
description:
Can a sport klutz reach her dream and dance?  
A charming and hilarious slice of life, middle-grade graphic novel about ten-year-old Electra who refuses to give up her dream to take ballet. 

After moving, Ellie feels lonely in her new class. Mom has a solution; the girl needs to join the school’s sports team to make friends. There is only one problem, no matter what sport she tries, Electra makes an utter fool of herself. In the middle of her misery, enchanted by her cousin’s ballet performance, Ellie suddenly knows what she wants more than anything, dancing. If only mom could agree.  
 
A page turner full of relatable conflicts, Ellie in First Position is a humorous, positive and heartwarming story about resilience, self-love, new experiences, and friendship.  

By the end of the book, Ellie not only learns to accept herself and her family, but also makes new friends, has her first crush, and manages to deal with her bullies too. 

Fans of The Babysitters Club, Fancy Nancy, or the Stepping Stones series will love Ellie in First Position.
author_bio:
Brian Freschi has worked in the theatre and the performing arts for many years. He studied scriptwriting at the Accademia Internationale di Comics in Florence and has collaborated with the Manticora Collective since 2015. Brian’s books have been released by numerous publishers of children’s literature and comics. His work has been translated in many countries, including France and the U.S. He teaches scriptwriting at The Sign Academy in Florence and was nominated as Best Writer in the 2020 Boscarato Awards at the Treviso Comic Book Festival. 

 AMAZON Author’s PAGE of Brian Freschi 

https://www.amazon.com/stores/Brian-Freschi/author/B08DCZ21GP?ref=ap_rdr&store_ref=ap_rdr&isDramIntegrated=true&shoppingPortalEnabled=true
illustrator_bio: Elena Triolo is an illustrator and cartoonist from Tuscany. She has worked with the major Italian publishing houses and many different brands, and she teaches comics and illustration to adults and children. Elena has two major passions—drawing and ballet—and has a huge following on social media under her profile, @carotecannella. Ellie in First Position is the dynamic duo’s first graphic novel together.

title: Giant Baby!
author: Liz Rosenberg
subtitle: The World Is His Plaything
description:
A silly, fun, and funny bedtime adventure. 

Ever wonder where your baby goes at night when you think he’s asleep in his crib? Like most babies, he grows bigger . . . taller . . . HUGER! A Giant Baby! Bulldozers and garbage trucks become his toys. Shipping containers and skyscrapers become blocks, the moon becomes a nightlight, and the whole world becomes a playground. 

Until, that is, Ezra’s parents want to check on him in bed. And then it’s stomp stomp stomp back home. Can he make it back inside his crib in time? 

From Liz Rosenberg (Monster Mama) and Eva Byrne (Along Came Coco), this fun and funny bedtime adventure follows baby Ezra, who waits until his parents are asleep to grow bigger, taller, HUGER . . . and to make the city itself his plaything
author_bio:
Born in Glen Cove, NY, Liz Rosenberg is the author of novels, poetry, biographies and more than 25 children’s books, including her most recent, SCRIBBLES, SORROWS AND RUSSET LEATHER BOOTS: A Biography of Louisa May Alcott and HOUSE OF DREAMS: A Biography of L.M. Montgomery, a Goodreads Top 10 History Book.  

She has published in The New Yorker, The New York Times, Washington Post, Harper’s, The Atlantic Monthly, LitHub and elsewhere, and served twice as judge for the National Book Awards. She teaches English and Creative Writing at Binghamton University, where she received the Chancellor’s Award for Excellence in Undergraduate Teaching.
illustrator_bio: Eva Byrne is the author-illustrator of Along Came Coco and Supernana, the former a Bank Street Book of the Year selection. She also illustrated the New York Times best-selling Princesses Wear Pants, co-written by Today show host Savannah Guthrie, and Piglette, written by Katelyn Aronson. Eva resides on Ireland’s west coast.
author_long_bio:
I guess you could add, among her awards and prizes she has received a Fulbright Fellowship to Northern Ireland; a Pennsylvania Council of the Arts Award; an IRA Children’s Choice Award; A Silver Hugo Award, and featured on Reading Rainbow. She was book columnist for the Boston Globe for more than 20 years, and a documentary film on her life and work, How a Writer is Made, was produced by Green Light Press.  

She splits her time between upstate NY and coastal Connecticut, and lives with her partner John Swenson. Her children live close enough for frequent visits, as does the original Giant Baby, her grandson Max David Bosnick, who lives in New Jersey.
author_marketing_additional_notes: I have been a Jewish Book Network Pick, and also a Junior Book of the Month Club Pick. I’d try leaning on Scholastic Book Club but don’t have any particular connection there– however they have chosen my books in the past.
about_summary: It seems to Ezra’s mom and dad that their baby is growing up overnight. Little do they know that later that same night he will burst through his footsie pajamas and wander the city streets as GIANT BABY.
about_promotable_points: Humor– relatability– what parent doesn’t feel as if their baby is getting bigger every day? –child fantasies of enormous strength and size. it’s like the classic book, GEORGE SHRINKS– in reverse!
about_audience: Babies, toddlers, and the grownups who love them.
about_dates_holidays: I think this will depend a lot on the illustrator. Is it going to be a summer book? Spring or fall? Those could factor in– but no, it has no direct relation to a particular holiday or event. Maybe the nice thing is that the book is relevant and appropriate for little ones year around.
author_publicity_additional_notes: I have been a Jewish Book Network Pick, and also a Junior Book of the Month Club Pick. I’d try leaning on Scholastic Book Club but don’t have any particular connection there– however they have chosen my books in the past.

title: I Said No!
author: Zack King & Kimberly King
subtitle: A Kid-to-kid Guide to Keeping Private Parts Private
description:
I Said No: A Kid-to-kid Guide to Keeping Private Parts Private, a Mom’s Choice Award recipient, gets a much-needed makeover with updated text and all-new artwork. This Marble Press edition of the popular book will continue to help families navigate a difficult subject in simple, kid-friendly language that advises readers to identify their feelings, recognize green and red flags, and to always (always) confide in a trusted adult when encountering the red ones. 

Praise for I Said No! 

"A compassionate, age-appropriate guide to helping children understand and assert their personal boundaries, [and] a vital resource for parents, caregivers, and educators."—Renee Reina, PhD, host of The Mom Room Podcast. 

“When it comes to sexual abuse prevention, I Said No! is the perfect starting point. A must-read for parents, caregivers, and the children they love, this book provides clear, kid-friendly information about bodies, safety, and what to do when something doesn't feel right. Armed with accurate information, your child will be better prepared to spot "red flag" feelings and behaviors.” --Betsy Kanarowski, PhD, LCSW, Chief Clinical Officer, Saprea
author_bio:
Kimberly King is a best-selling author, child safety educator, and speaker known for her research-based, kid-friendly books on body safety, including Body Safety for Young Children: Empowering Caring Adults. 

Her books are recommended by many prevention organizations, The  Child Mind Institute and Harvard Graduate School of Education. Kimberly is a volunteer community educator for Saprea.org and D2L.Org 

Find her books, workshops, and resources at www.kimberlykingbooks.com and follow @ToughTopicsMom for expert tips.
illustrator_bio: Susan Szecsi is a classically trained illustrator and visual storyteller. Susan has worked with clients such as Scholastic, Chicago Review Press, and Stanford University Press. When not illustrating, she is the managing director and art director for Marble Press, based in Palo Alto, California, where she lives with her husband.
author_long_bio:
Kimberly King is a best-selling author, child safety expert, and leading voice in body safety education. With over 250,000 books sold, her research-based, kid-friendly books—including I Said No! A Kid-to-Kid Guide to Keeping Private Parts Private—help parents, educators, and caregivers protect children from abuse. Her work is recommended by the Child Mind Institute, Harvard Graduate School of Education, and the Journal of Child Sexual Abuse for its accessible and empowering approach.   

As a notable speaker at National Education for Young Children and Johns Hopkins School of Public Health, Kimberly provides expert training for schools, organizations, and conferences. She offers online classes, private consultations, and body safety workshops for families and educators, making prevention strategies easy and actionable. Her latest book, Body Safety for Young Children: Empowering Caring Adults, serves as a practical guide for parents and teachers.   

Kimberly’s expertise has been featured on ABC News The Motherside, Child Mind Institute, and cited in academic research. She actively volunteers with Saprea.org, supporting survivors and raising awareness about child abuse prevention. With a background in education and decades of experience, she is committed to helping families have age-appropriate, empowering conversations about safety and boundaries.   

Whether through her books, online courses, or speaking engagements, Kimberly equips parents and professionals with the tools they need to prevent child sexual abuse before it happens. Learn more at www.kimberlykingbooks.com 

and follow @ToughTopicsMom on social media.

about_summary:
I Said No! A Kid-to-Kid Guide to Keeping Private Parts Private is  a best-selling, research-based book that empowers children with essential body safety skills. Written from a child’s perspective, this trusted resource helps kids understand body boundaries, consent, and helps kids identify their emotions and seek help if they feel  unsafe.   

This updated edition includes beautiful, light, empowering illustrations , modern safety concerns, such as online safety, video game stranger danger, and social media risks. It introduces expanded definitions of "safe adults”, helping children identify trustworthy individuals both in-person and online. Realistic what if?” scenarios prepare kids to recognize and respond to red flags in chat rooms, friend requests, and text messages.  

With age-appropriate language, engaging illustrations, and practical conversation starters, this book makes tough topics accessible. Recommended by the Child Mind Institute, Harvard Graduate School of Education, and the Journal of Child Sexual Abuse, it is a must-have for families, schools, and caregivers.   

I Said No! provides children with the tools to set boundaries, seek help, and stay safe—both offline and online.
about_promotable_points: Kid-friendly, not-icky, research based effective strategies that have been shown to effect predict the risks of child sexual abuse.   ( study by Eleanor Craig)

title: Into the Deep Blue
author: Jennifer E. Archer
description:
Perfect for fans of Nicola Yoon’s The Sun is Also a Star and John Green’s The Fault in Our Stars,  Into the Deep Blue is Fiona and Nick’s achingly moving, wry, and hopeful tale about falling apart and coming together told from two unforgettable points of view, 

Nick and Fiona were meant to be friends—best friends—and they wouldn’t change that for the world. At least, that’s what they tell themselves. Because they can’t be an us. Nick doesn’t believe in happy endings ever since they both lost their moms unexpectedly senior year. And Fiona often wonders if all they have in common is their numb hearts. Still, they’re content to share everything else with each other. Honestly. Everything but sparks.  

But when Fiona accidentally lets her guard down more than she intended to with Nick, it threatens to ruin their fragile balancing act. Luckily, Nick isn’t about to let a little misunderstanding get in the way of the weekend trip they’ve been planning for months. Fiona is just hoping for some closure on the first anniversary of her mom’s death—except grief isn’t that simple, and choosing to love again isn’t, either. Now the only thing standing between Fiona and Nick is the truth. They just need the courage to reach for it. 

“Into the Deep Blue is YA contemporary at its best. Archer’s rich, complicated characters, spitfire pacing, and heartfelt interactions intertwine so effortlessly on every page. Nick and Fiona will steal your hearts in this layered expression of grief and hope, heartache and healing. A true gem.” —Laura Taylor Namey, New York Times bestselling author of A Cuban Girl’s Guide to Tea and Tomorrow
author_bio:
Jennifer E. Archer is an author and screenwriter based in Toronto. Her screenplay, Into the Deep Blue, won the Academy Nicholl Fellowships in Screenwriting and the hearts of many.  

When she’s not writing, she can be found hiding behind a book, re-watching Pride and Prejudice, or trying to find peace in nature—really trying. Into the Deep Blue is her first novel.  

Visit her online at jenniferarcherwrites.com or on Instagram @jennwrites
author_long_bio:
Jennifer E. Archer is an author and screenwriter based in Toronto. Her screenplay, Into The Deep Blue, won the Academy Nicholl Fellowships in Screenwriting and the hearts of many.  

Jennifer writes stories rooted in reality with just a hint of magic because what’s life without a bit of magic? Her stories are always full of adventure, heartache, and hope.  

When she’s not writing, she can be found hiding behind a book, re-watching Pride and Prejudice, or trying to find peace in nature—really trying. Into The Deep Blue is her first novel.  

Visit her online at jenniferarcherwrites.com or on Instagram @jennwrites
about_summary: (Jodi’s beautiful flap copy might help here? But here are some previous bits I had.) Short logline: Into the Deep Blue follows Nick and Fiona, best friends who met in group therapy, struggling to put the pieces of their lives together after loss. The last thing they need is to fall in love. When a weekend trip brings their deepening feelings to the surface they might sooner cut each other off than face them. Slightly longer one here: Nick Bennet is an expert at messing up. Maybe not as much as his older sister, but he really upped his game by getting a DUI, a license suspension, and mandatory grief counseling after their mom died. Now, he’s trying to put the pieces of his life together. He wants to get away from his family and go to college in New York to be a writer, but his dad is betting against him. Nick will mess up again—it’s what he does best. The last thing he needs is to fall in love with Fiona, his only friend from therapy. His only friend—period. With Fiona, he can be himself, darkly funny, lonely, a closet optimist, and more honest than he’s ever been in his life. Fiona gets it—this rollercoaster called grief—she’s stuck on it too. Fiona’s everything he’s not. She socializes in therapy, her gymnastics students adore her, and she has actual friends who care about her.
about_promotable_points: The screenplay for the book won the Academy Nicholl Fellowship.
A movie is being made! (Although reluctant to use the actors directly for promotion.)

Guaranteed a happy ending!
Being made into a movie.

title: LINDEN
author: Colleen Muske
subtitle: The Story of a Tree
description:
Some trees grow up wanting to be tall lighthouses or big red barns full of horses. Not Linden. He is grateful just being a tree. Through snowy winters full of caroling to summertime picnics beneath his shady boughs, Linden watches over the people who love and care for him.

Colleen Muske’s heartfelt, gorgeously illustrated ode to the simple joys of loving one’s community is full of childlike wonder and comfort in the many ways nature supports and surprises us.
author_bio: Colleen has been drawing horses in the margins of her homework since she can remember. You will find the patterns and colors of nature throughout her paintings. Full of animals, trees, and Minnesota winters, Colleen’s stories are inspired by everyday life and her quiet, lyrical view of the world.
author_long_bio:
Colleen Muske has been practicing art her whole life. When her 6th grade teacher told her she had talent, she decided to become a real artist. She has studied at Minneapolis Community College, Minneapolis College of Art and Design, and many artists’ private studios. Colleen likes to say she is community educated since her most valuable education is from fellow artists, workshops, and conferences. 

After taking her first Children’s Book Illustration class, Colleen knew she had found her calling. Writing classes at The Loft Literary Center soon followed. Many classes and many drafts later, her stories are coming to life! Colleen’s art is full of nature, animals, and everyday life. Her favorite artists are Grandma Moses, Barbara Cooney and Henri Matisse, Colleen’s artwork is overflowing with pattern, color, and texture. 

Colleen lives in Stillwater, Minnesota with her husband in a 146-year-old house. They share their house with three dogs and two cats who inspire many of her stories.

about_summary: Linden is a book about a tree and how he affects the lives of the community around him. The illustrations show Linden from the day he was planted in 1907 to current day. The community that lives around him enjoys all the things Linden has to offer, such as shade, a home for birds and squirrels, creative inspiration, and a place to gather. When Linden gets sick, the community comes together to help him, but nothing works. Linden is grateful he was so useful and loved by the community. When Linden is gone, it changes the way the community lives and interacts with each other. But Linden leaves a secret behind and soon everyone realizes how much Linden loved them back.
about_promotable_points: Linden is about community.
How nature can bring people together.
How important nature is in our lives.
about_diff_competitors: It’s told from the perspective of the tree.
The many ways a tree can affect the daily lives of the people and animals around it.
Linden takes place in a city and not the country or a big back yard or woods.

title: Rafa and the Wrong Legs
author: Angie Lucas
description:
Rafael is finally old enough to visit the supermarket without having to ride in the shopping cart. He promises Mama he will stay by her side, and for a while, he does . . . especially when tasting samples from the Cookie Man. But after a bouncing berry lures him away, Rafa wanders into a sea of unfamiliar legs. Will he ever find his way back to Mama? 

Rafa and the Wrong Legs is a sweet, clever, and wise story that every parent and curious child will recognize as their own. A special Q&A at the end contains expert advice about what to do should your own little Rafa ramble off in a public place.
author_bio: Angie Lucas is a children’s book writer who used to edit magazines, compose ad copy, and ghostwrite for tech CEOs. Now she writes little stories about big, embarrassing elephants; big, dumb, invisible dragons; and little boys who get lost in grocery stores. She firmly believes that sunlight is the best antidote to shame—and that it takes time, attention, and compassionate connection to tame an unruly elephant. A graduate of Utah State University, Angie lives with her precious patchwork family (she has one child through marriage, one through adoption, and one through birth), near Salt Lake City.
illustrator_bio: Ana Sanfelippo is an artist and graphic designer from Buenos Aires, Argentina. She is the illustrator of the IBBY-honored Perfect Project: A Book about Autism, selected as an “Outstanding Book for Young People with Disabilities.” Among other accolades, her illustrated collection of pottery received a “Good Design Seal” from Buenos Aires’ Metropolitan Design Center. Her vibrant art combines many by-hand techniques and has exhibited in Argentina, Slovakia, England, Canada, and Spain. Find her at anasanfelippo.com
author_long_bio:
Angie Lucas used to edit magazines, compose ad copy, and ghostwrite articles for tech CEOs. Now she writes little stories about big childhood challenges. Through picture books about grief and loss, embarrassing family secrets, and getting lost in a grocery store, she hopes to spark essential conversations between kids and their caregivers. A lifelong language lover and unapologetic word nerd, Angie also loves yoga, freshly sharpened pencils, fresh mountain air, and volunteering in her faith community. The mother of one child through marriage, one through adoption, and one through birth, Angie lives with her precious patchwork family near Salt Lake City, Utah.

Present professional position:  

Children’s author and freelance writer

about_summary: Rafa and the Wrong Legs: Little Rafa has lost his mother. One minute, he’s clinging to her calf while she picks out produce. The next, a bouncing berry leads him astray, and he finds himself tugging on a complete stranger’s trousers! Mortified, Rafa runs deeper into the unfamiliar grocery aisles. With so many different kinds of legs wandering past, how will Rafa ever find his way back to Mama? Rafa’s story will spark important conversations between parents and preschoolers about what to do (and what not to do) if they ever get lost in a public place, with helpful tips and a discussion guide included in the back matter.
about_promotable_points: Safety. This story is a fun and accessible way to teach kids about the importance of staying near caregivers when out in public, with tips about what to do if they ever get lost.
Humor.

Food vocabulary. This story mentions lots of familiar and less common produce items to help pique kids’ interest in different kinds of healthful foods, including artichokes, honeydew, pistachios, etc.
about_bookstore_shelf: Picture books   Social-Emotional Learning titles   Mental health
about_diff_competitors: The story is not overly instructive or didactic. It’s a fun and engaging story with subtle lessons that can be teased out.
The back matter has practical, memorable, and useful tips to help parents and teachers teach children how to keep themselves safe if they ever get lost.
This is an important safety topic, but it’s written in a way that will not be scary or anxiety inducing, which will put kids in a better frame of mind to absorb its lessons.

title: One Alley Summer
author: Anne Ylvisaker
subtitle: A Novel about Friendship and Growing Up
description:
The summer before middle school is a time of anxiety and change. A pitch-perfect novel in verse about one girl’s wish to simultaneously break free and to belong. 

In the summer before her first year of middle school, word-chanting, rope-skipping Phee skips her way to imagined fame, writes down her innermost secret thoughts from the safety of a treehouse, and imagines in horror that her new classmates will eat her alive. Suddenly, her well-worn alley world feels too small. So when Mercy Jones moves next door, along with Mercy’s skateboard and her don’t-mess-with-me attitude, Phee sees the chance for her universe to expand. Even if it means leaving some things behind . . . It is a time of dares, of a legendary dog named Bull, of stretching comfort zones, and of old friendships made over in new ways. And it all takes place over the course of one alley summer. 

Using pitch-perfect, richly rendered verse, Anne Ylvisaker captures the tone and insights of one girl’s wish to simultaneously break free and to belong.

title: The Adventures of Penguin and Panda
author: Brenda Maier
series: The Adventures of Penguin and Panda
subtitle: Winterfest
description:
A wintry collection of four all-new stories featuring excitable Penguin and her chill BFF, Panda. Whether earning money for the perfect Christmas tree; shopping for a cozy new holiday sweater; sledding down a terrifyingly snowy hill; or trying to squeeze in everything on Penguin’s over-the-top Christmas list, these two yin and yang besties meet every challenge with an abundance of humor and generosity of spirit. Full of clever dialogue, giggle-inducing artwork, and even a few fun facts.

For fans of Narwhal & Jelly; Beak & Ally; and Pizza & Taco.

about_summary: Penguin and Panda should not be friends. The very idea is absurd. Penguin likes to build things and Panda likes to nap. Panda munches bamboo and Penguin gobbles cheese puffs and jam-banana sandwiches. Penguin never powers down and Panda has a hard time powering up. There is no way their friendship would ever work. Except somehow, it does.
about_promotable_points: It’s got two best friends who are polar opposites, but they can still be friends.
The characters’ experiences mirror those of children’s. Kids struggle with emotions like frustration, guilt, and anger just like Penguin and Panda do.
They’re positive. Even if someone makes a mistake, the stories center on hope, positivity, and kindness.
about_bookstore_shelf: In the early graphic chapter book section, or wherever Narwhal & Jelly is.
about_diff_competitors: Penguin & Panda focuses on very authentic, relatable, child-mirroring situations.
There’s a bit of wisdom in each book. There’s a sort of generalized bit of knowledge or philosophy in each one.
Though the characters struggle with various things, they are kind and empathetic, always with a happy ending. You can count on them.
about_audience: Elementary school-aged kids from 5-10, depending on their ability to read. I don’t see this as a read-aloud that teachers will do, but we might be able to market them for reading groups with questions to download. And of course they’re super engaging for classroom libraries and kids shopping with their parents.

title: The Adventures of Penguin and Panda
author: Brenda Maier
series: The Adventures of Penguin and Panda
subtitle: In the Dark
description:
Beloved odd-couple Penguin and Panda return in four new adventures. Whether it’s Penguin’s first campout (in the dark!) or her strange competition with the new neighbor, she is definitely feeling all the feels. Panda, Mr. Low-Key, is always happy to offer up sage wisdom, but his inability to stop putting things off comes back to bite him when he ruins a special Fun Friday. 

Penned by a gifted-education specialist, and full of hilarious illustrations and a generous spirit of friendship, In the Dark is perfect for early readers. If you’ve enjoyed Narwhal and Jelly, give this funny duo a try.

author_bio: Brian Anderson is the author of The Conjurers trilogy. He is also an optioned screenwriter and the creator of the syndicated comic strip “Dog Eat Doug.” He lives in North Carolina with his family, which includes a herd of rescued dogs and cats.

about_promotable_points: Family friendly
Humor for young and old readers
about_diff_competitors: Dog eat Doug has a proven track record of appealing to readers of all ages. Grandparents read it to their grandkids, parents share it with their kids.
Dog eat Doug, much like Pixar films, is known for multi-layered humor to entertain audiences of all ages.
Kids and adults relate to it because it reflects their own lives. I constantly get accused of hiding cameras in my readers’ homes.
about_audience: Kids ages 4-12 will be the majority of the audience. But these are characters a lot of people fell in love with when they were young and some have kids of their own now. My goal is to make these books families will read together.
about_dates_holidays: There is a giant demand for family friendly entertainment as evidenced by the continuing popularity of Peanuts and Calvin and Hobbes. While Dog eat Doug shared newspaper space with both of those comics, it is uniquely positioned to expand beyond the limited four panel world.

description: Get ready for double the fun with the Sophie series, launching two awesome books in 2024! In Frankenstein’s Hound (Book 2), join a gang of foster puppies on a dragon hunt, witness Sophie and Jack’s epic battle against the Ninja Socks, and brace yourself for the mischievous duo, Chewy and Equi, who create a Cat-ificial intelligence robot thinking just just like them. Ever wondered what the Yeti of Enlightenment has to spill about the secret of happiness? And who’s that mysterious giant lurking behind Doug and Sophie on the cover? Dive into the book and unravel the excitement yourself!

title: Sophie
author: Brian Anderson
subtitle: Wags to Wishes
description:
A JLG Gold Standard selection  

Praised as “reminiscent of Calvin and Hobbes” by Kirkus Reviews, and “the perfect mix of heart, humor, and hilarity” by Big Nate creator Lincoln Peirce, this comic strip-turned-graphic-novel series hits the sweet spot for both kids and any pet-obsessed grownups. 

Wags to Wishes, Book 3 of this middle-grade graphic novel series starring Sophie the chocolate lab, pokes gently at family power structures. Still reeling from all the new additions to her family (a human baby along with various stray dogs and cats), Sophie decides that – as the alpha – it is up to her to protect them all. And so she tries . . . from an island of temptation made entirely of desserts, to an army of discarded chew toys seeking revenge for lost squeakers, to the cats’ unending pursuit to rule humanity, Sophie’s adventures are epic, fun, and funny.

title: The Little Wolf's Howl
author: Nelly Buchet
subtitle: A Story of Getting Lost, Only to Find One’s Voice
description:
A Story of Finding One’s Voice in the World 

When Little Wolf becomes separated from her family, she remembers her mama’s advice: If you’re ever lost, find North. But who or what is North? 

With a little help from new friends Whale, Goose, and Bear, Little Wolf finds her own way North—and, eventually, back home. 

In this tale about discovering one’s voice, playful storytelling, gentle humor, and vibrant illustrations create the perfect winter picture book for little wolves everywhere.
author_bio: Nelly Buchet (www.nellybuchet.com) is the author of many books for young readers, including ALA Notable selection Cat DogDog, which was chosen by children around the world as the winner of 2021’s Irma Black Award for Excellence in Children’s Literature. Nelly has always loved wolves. She wrote her first story about a wolf mother and her pups when she was four. Thankfully, her father helped transcribe it and it became, with time, the book before you know.
illustrator_bio: Mathias Ball (www.MathiasBall.com) is a trans-identified illustrator born and raised in a small Canadian lakeside town. You can typically find their work featuring animals, emotion, and a whimsy of colors. They area graduateof the Illustration program at Sheridan College, with their work being recognized by Society of Illustrators, Communication Arts, 3×3 Illustration, and more.

about_summary:
Finding North is the endearing story of Loulou, a lost wolf cub who must prove (to herself) that she is a real wolf and find the great and fearsome North to rejoin her family. On the way, she meets migrating animals who help her gain the skills she needs to find North...and her pack. Finding North is an empowering story about finding oneself (one's north!) and understanding that belonging comes with accepting ourselves for who we are, no matter what others think. 

 

Finding North offers layers of poignant, relatable SEL and gentle humor in this story about being true to oneself.
about_promotable_points: A funny and poignant story full of SEL
Understanding that believing in oneself is more important than what others think about you
STEAM points (migration, wolves and apex predators as key ecosystem engineers/as it relates to the climate/politics of extinction, etc)
about_bookstore_shelf: Front and center! I’ve written concept books, and I love them, but I also love a good adventure. That’s what Finding North is. Both traditional, in the sense of a real quest, and modern/contemporary/hip! as it relates to the freshness of the style and voice. Finding North has both a modern twist and a classical feel (with the chorus “Are you North?), much like family favorites such as The Gruffalo.
about_diff_competitors: Finding North has a very strong voice. It is first and foremost a story about being a kid.

Finding North is a good story about a lovable character that all children (and adults!) can relate to. It is emotionally rich, from funny to heartbreaking to heartwarming, with a satisfying character arc, ending, and message.
about_audience:
I see fans of The Gruffalo and Stellaluna. 
Comparing ourselves to the people in our lives starts early—at school, on the playground, at home with siblings. We want our teeth to fall out. We want to know how to read immediately! We want to sit at the big kids’ table but we’re told we’re too small. We can all relate to this feeling. In Finding North, Loulou ends up understanding that she doesn’t actually need to prove anything to others. Only to herself.
about_dates_holidays:
International Wolf Day is August 13.  
International Siblings Day is April 10.  
A personal note: I love wolves. I always have. Finding North is inspired by the very first story I “wrote” with my father before I could hold a pen. I have an assignment from elementary school where I drew a poster to urge people to save wolves. Will be sharing on social media closer to pub J
